docs.lead_paragraph: What mother in her right mind -- no matter how affluent -- would spend nearly $2,000 on a coat that her daughter will outgrow in a few months? At a time when thousands of pension plans have vaporized overnight, when prescription drugs cost, well, as much as a designer shearling coat and when millions have no health insurance, there's only one word for a story like this: obscene. Susan Bodiker Washington
docs.abstract: Letter from Susan Bodiker says July 28 Style photos of children wearing $2,000 coats was obscene

docs.lead_paragraph: The longshoremen's union is angrily accusing the Bush administration of siding with management in a contract dispute that threatens to shut down all West Coast ports. Officials with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union said a Labor Department official had told them the administration might order an 80-day cooling off period or have the military operate the ports if the union staged a strike or work slowdown.

headline.main: Longshoremen Accuse Government of Management Bias

docs.abstract: Longshoremen's union accuses Bush administration of siding with management in contract dispute that threatens to shut down all West Coast ports; union officials are angry that administration might order 80-day cooling off period or have military operate ports if union stages strike or work slowdown; longshoremen's contract expired July 1 and negotiations were suspended three weeks ago, with each side accusing other of making unrealistic proposals; administration officials and business executives fear job action at ports could wreak havoc on nation's already wobbly economy; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The longshoremen's union is angrily accusing the Bush administration of siding with management in a contract dispute that threatens to shut down all West Coast ports.    Officials with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union said a Labor...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration today formally rolled back some major protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton. But at the same time, it also set new standards for the use of personal information to market prescription drugs and other health care products. The new rules, the first comprehensive federal standards for medical privacy, will affect virtually every doctor, patient, hospital, drugstore and health insurance company in the United States.

headline.main: BUSH ROLLS BACK RULES ON PRIVACY OF MEDICAL DATA

docs.abstract: Bush administration, adopting first comprehensive federal standards for medical record privacy, drops some major protections adopted by Pres Bill Clinton; sets new standards for use of personal data to market prescription drugs and other health care products; provisions dropped required health care providers to get written consent from patients before using or disclosing personal medical data for treatment or paying claims; providers will instead have to notify patients of their remaining rights and seek written acknowledgment that notice was received; Health Sec Tommy G Thompson defends change, opposed by consumer advocates, patients' rights groups and others; Sen Edward M Kennedy scores it; new rules also guarantee patients access to their medical records (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration today formally rolled back some major protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton. But at the same time, it also set new standards for the use of personal information to market prescription...

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco, the big financial services company whose woes two years ago were in many ways a preview of the current corporate scandals, said yesterday that its turnaround efforts had failed, and analysts warned that the company might seek bankruptcy protection. The concession marked a sharp reversal for Gary C. Wendt, the former General Electric executive who received one of the most generous contracts in corporate history, worth at least $75 million, when he was hired in 2000 to salvage Conseco.

headline.main: Conseco Recovery Efforts Fail; A Bankruptcy Filing Is Possible

docs.abstract: Conseco Inc announces that its turnaround efforts failed; analysts warn big financial services company might seek bankruptcy protection; chairman and chief executive Gary C Wendt hires lawyers and investment bankers to seek to reduce company's debts; he got one of most generous compensation packages in corporate history when he was hired in 2000 to salvage Conseco; regulators say Conseco policyholders are protected; photo (M)

byline.original: By FLOYD NORRIS and JOSEPH B. TREASTER

docs.lead_paragraph: Bush Adopts New Rules For Medical Data Privacy The Bush administration formally rolled back some major protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton. But at the same time, it also set new standards for the use of personal data to market prescription drugs and other health care products. The rules, the first comprehensive federal standards for medical privacy, will affect virtually every doctor, patient, hospital, drugstore, health insurance company and medical researcher in the United States. The rules embody more than five years of work and have the force of law. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Larry A. Silverstein, the developer, and Swiss Re, a major insurer of the World Trade Center, submitted settlement offers to a federal judge yesterday and then resumed their battle over insurance coverage of the trade center. The developer, who held the lease on the trade center when it was attacked, and his partners have argued in a series of lawsuits that they are entitled to a double payment of $7 billion because two planes hit two towers in what they describe as two separate ''occurrences'' on Sept. 11.

headline.main: Settlement Offers Fail to End Trade Center Insurance Battle

docs.abstract: Leaseholder Larry A Silverstein and Swiss Re, major insurer of World Trade Center, submit settlement offers to federal court and then resume battle over Silverstein's demand for double payment of $7 billion because two planes hit two towers in what they describe as separate 'occurences' on Sept 11 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, concerned about rising medical costs, said yesterday that his agency planned to step up scrutiny of past hospital mergers and groups of doctors to make sure they had not joined forces simply to fix prices. The chairman, Timothy J. Muris, said in an interview that the commission had increased spending 50 percent on its antitrust efforts in health care, which also include the review of the drug and health insurance industries.

headline.main: U.S. to Step Up Antitrust Effort On Health Care

docs.abstract: Federal Trade Commission's Chairman Timothy J Murtis says his agency will step up scrutiny of past hospital mergers and groups of doctors to make sure they have not joined simply to fix prices; voices concern about rising medical costs; says FTC has increased spending on antitrust efforts in health care by 50 percent, including review of drug and health insurance industries; agency's efforts to persuade federal courts to stop hospital mergers have been largely unsuccessful; new focus will be on determining whether previous mergers have actually benefited patients or simply allowed hospitals to charge more; antitrust lawyers believe commission may have easier time now, after mergers, if it can show evidence of higher prices (M)
docs.snippet: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, concerned about rising medical costs, said yesterday that his agency planned to step up scrutiny of past hospital mergers and groups of doctors to make sure they had not joined forces simply to fix...

docs.lead_paragraph: GENERAL MOTORS has a problem. It has promised its workers big pensions and generous health care benefits when they retire. Paying for those promises will not be easy. Not that it is especially easy to figure that out from G.M.'s financial statements. Accounting rules do not force companies to immediately face up to bad news from their pension plans. So the balance sheet impact is delayed. Eventually, however, reality will win out, and General Motors will have to come up with the money.

headline.main: Pension Woes Bring Business Wealth Effect

docs.abstract: Floyd Norris column says combination of poor stock market returns and low interest rates threaten many companies with defined pension plans, like General Motors Corp, whose retirement benefits plans, including pensions and health care, have unfinanced liabilities of $61 billion, up from $34 billion in 1999; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More doctors are making house calls, now that they pay more. Medicare in 1998 raised payments for home visits by as much as 50 percent, and the number of home visits that Medicare paid for last year shot up almost eightfold, to 1.5 million, up from 195,700 in 1996, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services found.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: More House Calls

docs.abstract: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services reports number of home visits by doctors paid for by Medicare soared by almost eightfold after Medicare raise payments for such visits (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: SO where are the economists? The latest data revisions from the Commerce Department show that the economy sank into recession well before Sept. 11, and not long after stock prices began to plummet. Consumer spending, which had been mysteriously strong, turned out to be significantly weaker. Little growth in the second quarter and July's paltry employment gains make the prospects of the dreaded double-dip recession a real possibility.

headline.main: Economic Scene; Let's hear from those who feel government has a role in stabilizing the economy.

docs.abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column assesses government's role in stabilizing economy; comments on views of late Hyman Minsky, economic theoretician who argued that because financial markets at some point lead to excessive investment and speculation, economy itself is prone to instability and that government itself is necessary bulwark against recession, particularly through so-called automatic stabilizers like unemployment insurance and welfare; Charles J Whale and Jeffrey B Wenger, economists, argue that Minsky's view is more relevant than ever because nation's automatic stabilizers are much weaker than they once were; photo (M)
